rows.title: Praise Yourself

transcript.eng:
Self-praise can be really helpful, especially when we have difficult days. 

Think of your week and finish the following phrase: ‚ÄúThis week, I am proud of myself for ‚Ä¶‚Äù It can be anything, not just things about being a parent!

Think of one thing you did well today. Now wrap your arms around yourself and give yourself a big HUG!

rows.transcript:
Self-praise can be really helpful, especially when we have difficult days. 

Think of your week and finish the following phrase: ‚ÄúThis week, I am proud of myself for ‚Ä¶‚Äù It can be anything, not just things about being a parent!

Think of one thing you did well today. Now wrap your arms around yourself and give yourself a big HUG!

text_1.eng: Self-care is a key parenting tool. It starts with recognising how we feel.

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Great. And amazing that you are using this app ‚Äì it shows your commitment as a parent. Make sure you give yourself credit and praise for what you are doing.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Every day has its highs and lows. Praise yourself for being here and trying ‚Äì you are moving forward.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Sorry that things are difficult right now. Take a deep breath and know that you are valued.

text_1.eng: This week, we want to talk about the environment you **CREATE** for your child.

text_2.eng: A positive environment helps children feel safe and helps them learn.

rows.text_1: This week, we want to talk about the environment you **CREATE** for your child.
rows.text_2: A positive environment helps children feel safe and helps them learn.

rows.title: The ParentApp Garden

text_2.eng:
In ParentApp for Kids, we use the image of a garden to think about what children need in their lives to grow and thrive.¬†

Let‚Äôs see how **creating a positive environment** forms part of the garden image.

rows.text_2:
In ParentApp for Kids, we use the image of a garden to think about what children need in their lives to grow and thrive.¬†

Let‚Äôs see how **creating a positive environment** forms part of the garden image.

rows.title: The ParentApp Garden

text_1.eng: In the same way that all plants need sunlight to grow, all children need praise and positive encouragement from their caregivers.

media_transcript.eng:
Children thrive when caregivers respond to them with warmth, acceptance and praise. Just as the sun rises and sets every day, try to give your child some positive attention every day.¬†

Remember that what gets light will grow. When parents give positive attention to good behaviour with praise, children will be encouraged to behave that way more often in the future.

rows.text_1: In the same way that all plants need sunlight to grow, all children need praise and positive encouragement from their caregivers.
rows.media_transcript:
Children thrive when caregivers respond to them with warmth, acceptance and praise. Just as the sun rises and sets every day, try to give your child some positive attention every day.¬†

Remember that what gets light will grow. When parents give positive attention to good behaviour with praise, children will be encouraged to behave that way more often in the future.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here‚Äôs how you can create a positive environment for your child:

text_2.eng:
**Give positive instructions**

Positive instructions are more effective than negative instructions. Telling children what we DO want them to do works better than telling them to STOP doing something.

media_transcript.eng:
Let‚Äôs say you are visiting a friend, and your children are playing together. As they play, you notice that your child sometimes shares the toys and other times grabs the toy from her friend. Instead of saying: ‚Äústop grabbing that toy!‚Äù you could say: ‚Äúgive your friend a chance to play with the toy‚Äù 

It is easier for children to follow instructions that tell them what they should do, rather than what they shouldn‚Äôt do.

rows.text_2:
**Give positive instructions**

Positive instructions are more effective than negative instructions. Telling children what we DO want them to do works better than telling them to STOP doing something.
rows.media_transcript:
Let‚Äôs say you are visiting a friend, and your children are playing together. As they play, you notice that your child sometimes shares the toys and other times grabs the toy from her friend. Instead of saying: ‚Äústop grabbing that toy!‚Äù you could say: ‚Äúgive your friend a chance to play with the toy‚Äù 

It is easier for children to follow instructions that tell them what they should do, rather than what they shouldn‚Äôt do.
rows.text_1_facilitator: Here‚Äôs how you can create a positive environment for your child:

text_1_facilitator.eng: Need some convincing? Let‚Äôs do an exercise:

text_2.eng:
DO NOT THINK ABOUT AN ELEPHANT.

What are you thinking about?

rows.text_2:
DO NOT THINK ABOUT AN ELEPHANT.

What are you thinking about?
rows.text_1_facilitator: Need some convincing? Let‚Äôs do an exercise:

text_2.eng:
You probably DID think about an elephant...

‚ÄòDon‚Äôt do‚Äô instructions make children think about that thing.

Sometimes they do not understand what we DID want from them.

Also they often don‚Äôt like being told not to do things (just like most of us).

rows.text_2:
You probably DID think about an elephant...

‚ÄòDon‚Äôt do‚Äô instructions make children think about that thing.

Sometimes they do not understand what we DID want from them.

Also they often don‚Äôt like being told not to do things (just like most of us).

text_2.eng:
NOW, THINK ABOUT A CHEETAH! 

What are you thinking about?

rows.text_2:
NOW, THINK ABOUT A CHEETAH! 

What are you thinking about?

text_2.eng: That‚Äôs right - a cheetah! Positive, clear instructions help children focus on what they should be doing.

media_transcript.eng:
Before, I used to raise my children the way I was raised: I would tell them ‚Äúdon‚Äôt do this, don‚Äôt do that.‚Äù We used to fight a lot, but things have really changed when I learnt about giving positive instructions.

Now I focus on the behaviour I want to see, and give clear and simple instructions to my children. It took time to learn to say ‚Äúplease do this‚Äù instead of ‚Äúdon‚Äôt do this.‚Äù 

My children and even my husband tell me that they love this way of doing things, because now they know what needs to be done.

rows.text_2: That‚Äôs right - a cheetah! Positive, clear instructions help children focus on what they should be doing.
rows.media_transcript:
Before, I used to raise my children the way I was raised: I would tell them ‚Äúdon‚Äôt do this, don‚Äôt do that.‚Äù We used to fight a lot, but things have really changed when I learnt about giving positive instructions.

Now I focus on the behaviour I want to see, and give clear and simple instructions to my children. It took time to learn to say ‚Äúplease do this‚Äù instead of ‚Äúdon‚Äôt do this.‚Äù 

My children and even my husband tell me that they love this way of doing things, because now they know what needs to be done.

text_2.eng:
**Use praise to encourage positive behaviour**
If we praise our children when they do something well, we will see them do more and more positive things!

section_1_text.eng: Sometimes it is hard to think of what to praise your child for! Here are some ideas from other parents:

section_1_extra_text.eng:
Being kind to someone¬†
Sharing their toys
Packing away their things 
Saying 'please' or 'thank you'¬†
Helping out around the house
Listening

rows.text_2:
**Use praise to encourage positive behaviour**
If we praise our children when they do something well, we will see them do more and more positive things!
rows.section_1_text: Sometimes it is hard to think of what to praise your child for! Here are some ideas from other parents:
rows.section_1_extra_text:
Being kind to someone¬†
Sharing their toys
Packing away their things 
Saying 'please' or 'thank you'¬†
Helping out around the house
Listening

rows.title: **Question time:**

text_2.eng: Think about the last time someone thanked you, or said you did something great.

quiz_1_question.eng: How did it make you feel?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Parents usually do not get thanked or praised enough.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Parents usually do not get thanked or praised enough.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Parents usually do not get thanked or praised enough.

quiz_2_question.eng: How does it make you feel when nobody says "thank you"?

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng: Your child can feel this way too. That's what makes this week's parenting tool simple but important: Praise them for what they do right.

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng: Your child can feel this way too. That's what makes this week's parenting tool simple but important: Praise them for what they do right.

quiz_2_feedback_3.eng: Your child can feel this way too. That's what makes this week's parenting tool simple but important: Praise them for what they do right.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Parents usually do not get thanked or praised enough.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Parents usually do not get thanked or praised enough.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Parents usually do not get thanked or praised enough.

rows.quiz_2_feedback_1: Your child can feel this way too. That's what makes this week's parenting tool simple but important: Praise them for what they do right.
rows.quiz_2_feedback_2: Your child can feel this way too. That's what makes this week's parenting tool simple but important: Praise them for what they do right.
rows.quiz_2_feedback_3: Your child can feel this way too. That's what makes this week's parenting tool simple but important: Praise them for what they do right.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let‚Äôs look at a story to see how you can use praise and positive attention to encourage your child to follow instructions:

character_1_text.eng: It‚Äôs so lovely to see you playing so nicely together, @data.characters.f3_girl.name and @data.characters.f3_boy_wheelchair.name. In five minutes it will be time to come inside and wash up.

media_title.eng: Let‚Äôs reflect on the caregiver‚Äôs actions:

media_transcript.eng: What does the caregiver do before she informs her children that they will have to stop playing in five minutes‚Äô time? She first brings attention to their positive behaviour of playing nicely together. This is a clever way to make it easier for the children to accept the next instruction.

rows.media_title: Let‚Äôs reflect on the caregiver‚Äôs actions:
rows.media_transcript: What does the caregiver do before she informs her children that they will have to stop playing in five minutes‚Äô time? She first brings attention to their positive behaviour of playing nicely together. This is a clever way to make it easier for the children to accept the next instruction.
rows.text_1_facilitator: Let‚Äôs look at a story to see how you can use praise and positive attention to encourage your child to follow instructions:
rows.character_1_text: It‚Äôs so lovely to see you playing so nicely together, @data.characters.f3_girl.name and @data.characters.f3_boy_wheelchair.name. In five minutes it will be time to come inside and wash up.

media_title.eng: Let‚Äôs reflect on the children‚Äôs perspective:

media_transcript.eng: The children are having fun playing in the garden. They might not want to stop playing in five minutes‚Äô time. If their mother came out and told them to come inside immediately (instead of giving them some warning), they may have found it difficult to listen and do what she asked.

rows.media_title: Let‚Äôs reflect on the children‚Äôs perspective:
rows.media_transcript: The children are having fun playing in the garden. They might not want to stop playing in five minutes‚Äô time. If their mother came out and told them to come inside immediately (instead of giving them some warning), they may have found it difficult to listen and do what she asked.

character_1_text.eng: @data.characters.f3_girl.name, @data.characters.f3_boy_wheelchair.name - it‚Äôs time to put the ball away and come inside now.

media_title.eng: Let‚Äôs reflect on the caregiver‚Äôs actions:

media_transcript.eng: The caregiver uses her children‚Äôs names so that she makes sure they will pay attention to what she is saying. She tells them exactly what she wants them to do. This makes it easier for her children to follow her instructions.

rows.media_title: Let‚Äôs reflect on the caregiver‚Äôs actions:
rows.media_transcript: The caregiver uses her children‚Äôs names so that she makes sure they will pay attention to what she is saying. She tells them exactly what she wants them to do. This makes it easier for her children to follow her instructions.
rows.character_1_text: @data.characters.f3_girl.name, @data.characters.f3_boy_wheelchair.name - it‚Äôs time to put the ball away and come inside now.

character_1_text.eng: Thank you for coming inside when I asked you to. Please go wash your hands and then I will tell you a story.

media_title.eng: Let‚Äôs reflect on the caregiver‚Äôs actions:

media_transcript.eng: The caregiver praises her children for their positive behaviour before giving them another instruction. As parents I‚Äôm sure some of you are thinking: why should I praise my child for just doing the basic things that they should be doing?! That‚Äôs a normal thought to have. But praise actually helps you as a parent and can make your life easier. By praising her children before giving them a new instruction, the children are more likely to listen and do what the caregiver is asking.

rows.media_title: Let‚Äôs reflect on the caregiver‚Äôs actions:
rows.media_transcript: The caregiver praises her children for their positive behaviour before giving them another instruction. As parents I‚Äôm sure some of you are thinking: why should I praise my child for just doing the basic things that they should be doing?! That‚Äôs a normal thought to have. But praise actually helps you as a parent and can make your life easier. By praising her children before giving them a new instruction, the children are more likely to listen and do what the caregiver is asking.
rows.character_1_text: Thank you for coming inside when I asked you to. Please go wash your hands and then I will tell you a story.

character_1_text.eng: Thank you for washing up so nicely. Let‚Äôs sit down and read a story together.

media_transcript.eng: By using clear, positive instructions and praise to encourage her children, this caregiver successfully managed to get her children to stop their game, come inside and wash their hands. This happened without threats, screaming, tears or tantrums. By reinforcing the praise with a simple reward - like reading a story together - she helps her children to follow instructions more easily in the future.

rows.media_transcript: By using clear, positive instructions and praise to encourage her children, this caregiver successfully managed to get her children to stop their game, come inside and wash their hands. This happened without threats, screaming, tears or tantrums. By reinforcing the praise with a simple reward - like reading a story together - she helps her children to follow instructions more easily in the future.
rows.character_1_text: Thank you for washing up so nicely. Let‚Äôs sit down and read a story together.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Remember that what gets light will grow!

text_2.eng: Positive instead of negative attention works much better to encourage children to behave the way we want them to.

rows.text_2: Positive instead of negative attention works much better to encourage children to behave the way we want them to.
rows.text_1_facilitator: Remember that what gets light will grow!

text_1.eng: Book activities are a great opportunity to give your child positive attention.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are some ideas for how you can create positive interactions during book activities:

rows.text_1: Book activities are a great opportunity to give your child positive attention.
rows.text_1_facilitator: Here are some ideas for how you can create positive interactions during book activities:

text_1.eng: As you go through the book together, respond to what your child is saying in a positive and enthusiastic way.

media_transcript.eng:
Using positive responses such as ‚Äúgreat‚Äù, ‚Äúwell done‚Äù, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs right‚Äù, ‚Äúyes, tell me more‚Äù, ‚Äúlet‚Äôs try‚Äù, ‚Äúhow about‚Äù or ‚Äúlet‚Äôs see‚Äù during book activities will encourage your child to feel confident to interact with the book and with you.¬†
When you speak in a positive and enthusiastic way, your child will feel excited and will be eager to learn from the book and the story.

rows.text_1: As you go through the book together, respond to what your child is saying in a positive and enthusiastic way.
rows.media_transcript:
Using positive responses such as ‚Äúgreat‚Äù, ‚Äúwell done‚Äù, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs right‚Äù, ‚Äúyes, tell me more‚Äù, ‚Äúlet‚Äôs try‚Äù, ‚Äúhow about‚Äù or ‚Äúlet‚Äôs see‚Äù during book activities will encourage your child to feel confident to interact with the book and with you.¬†
When you speak in a positive and enthusiastic way, your child will feel excited and will be eager to learn from the book and the story.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Being critical will discourage your child from speaking or engaging in the activity.

media_transcript.eng:
Book activities do not have to be serious. It is about sharing the book in a way that you and your child will enjoy, not about being strict or being right.¬†
So, if your child makes a mistake, avoid being critical or negative. You don‚Äôt have to be hard on your child, or make fun of them when they don‚Äôt know something.
When your child points to a picture and calls it the wrong name ‚Äì for example pointing to a tomato and calling it an apple, all you need to do is respond with the correct word. Instead of saying ‚Äúno, that is wrong! How can you say that‚Äôs an apple?!‚Äù just respond by saying ‚Äúthat‚Äôs a tomato‚Äù This will help them learn the correct word, without making them feel discouraged to try again.

rows.media_transcript:
Book activities do not have to be serious. It is about sharing the book in a way that you and your child will enjoy, not about being strict or being right.¬†
So, if your child makes a mistake, avoid being critical or negative. You don‚Äôt have to be hard on your child, or make fun of them when they don‚Äôt know something.
When your child points to a picture and calls it the wrong name ‚Äì for example pointing to a tomato and calling it an apple, all you need to do is respond with the correct word. Instead of saying ‚Äúno, that is wrong! How can you say that‚Äôs an apple?!‚Äù just respond by saying ‚Äúthat‚Äôs a tomato‚Äù This will help them learn the correct word, without making them feel discouraged to try again.
rows.text_1_facilitator: Being critical will discourage your child from speaking or engaging in the activity.

text_1.eng:
Three easy ways to use book activities to create positive interactions:
1. Respond in a positive way to what your child is saying
2. Avoid being critical or negative
3. Praise your child‚Äôs efforts.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Kindness and praise help children feel safe and confident, which helps them learn.

rows.text_1:
Three easy ways to use book activities to create positive interactions:
1. Respond in a positive way to what your child is saying
2. Avoid being critical or negative
3. Praise your child‚Äôs efforts.
rows.text_1_facilitator: Kindness and praise help children feel safe and confident, which helps them learn.

text_1.eng:
Small actions, big results! Parents who practice at home get better results.

For your home practice:
ü§ù Find opportunities to give your child positive attention every day.
üìñ Share books with your child in a fun and positive way.
üòå Remember to praise yourself too for your hard work as a parent.

rows.text_1:
Small actions, big results! Parents who practice at home get better results.

For your home practice:
ü§ù Find opportunities to give your child positive attention every day.
üìñ Share books with your child in a fun and positive way.
üòå Remember to praise yourself too for your hard work as a parent.
